BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow to low altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form on New Year's Eve especially in the regions exposed to precipitation. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. The older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: The new snow and wind slabs are bonding quite well with the old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The weather conditions facilitated a gradual strengthening of the snowpack in particular below approximately 2600 m. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In some localities 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday above approximately 2000 m. Until Monday the wind will be strong adjacent to ridgelines over a wide area. As a consequence of new snow and wind, mostly small wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on a crust in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2000 m. Wind slabs can be released easily. This applies even in case of a small load.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
The snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Some snow will fall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Old wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of snowfall and the moderate southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases. The avalanche danger will increase during the day. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2400 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Up to 15 cm of snow will fall from the afternoon above approximately 1500 m. The somewhat older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Some snow will fall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Old wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of snowfall and the moderate southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases. The avalanche danger will increase during the day. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2400 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Up to 15 cm of snow will fall from the afternoon above approximately 1500 m. The somewhat older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow will fall in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.
From early morning the wind will be strong at times in all regions.
The sometimes deep wind slabs will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. The fresh wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. They can in some cases be released easily. This applies even in case of a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2300 m.
In the morning and where less new snow falls, the danger of falling on hard snow remains, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steeper sections.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2300 m a lot of snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
The snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow will fall in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.
From early morning the wind will be strong at times in all regions.
The sometimes deep wind slabs will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. The fresh wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. They can in some cases be released easily. This applies even in case of a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2300 m.
In the morning and where less new snow falls, the danger of falling on hard snow remains, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steeper sections.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2300 m a lot of snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
The snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The snowpack will be stable. The older wind slabs are unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Some snow will fall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Old wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. As a consequence of snowfall and the moderate southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. This applies in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can reach medium size in isolated cases. The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above approximately 2400 m, depending on the infuence of the wind. Up to 15 cm of snow will fall from the afternoon above approximately 1500 m. The somewhat older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be quite stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs can at their margins be released by large loads. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in extremely steep terrain at high altitude.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The older wind slabs have bonded quite well with the old snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities up to 50 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1000 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In some localities wind and new snow: This applies especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In all aspects a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Hardly any snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The snowpack is stable and its surface has a resilient crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow to intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The weather conditions will cause a slight rise in the avalanche danger in the afternoon in the regions exposed to substantial precipitation. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally at elevated altitudes.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on the favourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger exists in particular in alpine snow sports terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: New snow is lying on a hard crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Some snow will fall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In all regions only a little snow is lying. As a consequence of snowfall and the moderate southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be quite stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The somewhat older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. Up to 15 cm of snow will fall from the afternoon above approximately 1500 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Little snow will fall from late morning in some localities.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. In some localities small wind slabs will form. The danger of dry avalanches will increase but remain within the current danger level.
The greatest danger remains slipping on hard snow, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steepest sections.
Fresh and older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
The snowpack is stable and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Little snow will fall from late morning in some localities.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. In some localities small wind slabs will form. The danger of dry avalanches will increase but remain within the current danger level.
The greatest danger remains slipping on hard snow, so it is advisable to carry snow knives and crampons for the steepest sections.
Fresh and older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls places that are protected from the wind, in particular on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
As a consequence of the strong to storm force wind, a crust formed on the surface. This applies above approximately 2600 m.
The snowpack is stable and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
